blocks.text: Use alcohol-based handrub before and after every procedure, such as before and after touching a patient, after touching patient's surroundings, before a clean procedure, after body fluid exposure risk and before and after wearing gloves.

Step by Step Preparation:
1. The alcohol (Ethanol or Isopropyl) for the formula to be used is poured into the large bottle or tank up to the graduated mark.

As glycerol is very viscous and sticks to the wall of the measuring cylinder, it should be rinsed with some sterile distilled or cold boiled water and then emptied into the bottle/tank.

5. The lid or the screw cap is placed on the tank/bottle as soon as possible after preparation, in order to prevent evaporation.

6. The solution is mixed by shaking gently where appropriate or by using a paddle.

6. The solution is mixed by shaking gently where appropriate or by using a paddle.
7. Immediately divide up the solution into its final containers (e.g. 500 or 100 ml plastic bottles), and place the bottles in quarantine for 72 hours before use.

Production and storage facilities should ideally be air conditioned or cool rooms. No naked flames or smoking should be permitted in these areas.

Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.
Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.
Manual vacuum aspiration, or MVA, is a technique for uterine evacuation whose low cost, simplicity and portability make it an especially valuable reproductive-health technology.
MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12-14 weeks.
MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12 weeks.
MVA is used for evacuation of the uterus at incomplete first trimester abortions up to a gestational age of 12 weeks.
Especially during septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed without delay.
Especially at septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed with no delay.
Especially at septic abortion and strong bleeding in relation to abortion the procedure is a life saving emergency procedure that must be performed with no delay.
Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.
Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.
Antibiotics should not delay the procedure.
Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.
Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.
Ideally antibiotics are given at the start of the procedure, though the procedure can be performed without antibiotics.
Cleaning After Use
Cleaning After Use
Cleaning After Use
Step 1:
Step 1:
Step 1:
Always wear utility gloves and an apron to protect from any splashes.
Immediately after use; discard the cannula and disassemble all items and soak instruments in a soap solution made of water and detergent.
Clean items with a brush in the solution.
Do not use bar soap for cleaning items.
If not possible, soak the items in the soap solution until cleaning is possible.
Soak instruments immediately after use
Soak instruments immediately after use
Rinse items with clean, running water.
All items should be individually inspected and visibly clean.
After cleaning, soak all items in a 0.5% chlorine solution to decontaminate for 10 minutes!
Following the procedure, decontaminate and clean all aspirators that will be reused, by first putting unlock and open jointed instruments in a 0.5 % chlorine solution for maximum 10 min.
Following the procedure, decontaminate and clean all aspirators that will be reused, by first putting unlock and open jointed instruments in a 0.5 % chlorine solution for maximum 10 min.
See procedure on how to mix a chlorine solution.
Hereafter clean the aspirators with a brush in a soap solution. Be aware the soap solution is made of detergent and water, not hand soap.
Hereafter clean the aspirators with a brush in a soap solution. Be aware the soap solution is made of detergent and water, not hand soap.
Rinse items with clean, running water, and air-dry before sterilisation or high-level disinfection.
Rinse items with clean running water to remove all detergent.
Rinse items with clean running water to remove all detergent.

Step 2:

Clean all aspirators thoroughly in warm water and detergent, not soap.
Clean all aspirators thoroughly in warm water and detergent, not soap.

Disassemble the aspirator by pulling the cylinder out of the valve.
Disassemble the aspirator by pulling the cylinder out of the valve.

Remove the cap by pressing down the cap-release tabs with one hand and pulling off the cap with the other hand.
Remove the cap by pressing down the cap-release tabs with one hand and pulling off the cap with the other hand.
Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.
Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.
Open the hinged valve by pulling open the clasp.
Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.
Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.
Place right thumb alongside the right valve button and left thumb on the valve latch.
With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.
With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.
With the left thumb, pull up and to the left on the valve latch while pushing down and out on the valve body with the right thumb.

Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:
Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:
Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:
If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.
If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.
If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.
The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.
The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.
The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.
All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.
All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.
All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is  increased.

Measurement of the foetal heart rate in childbirth is indicated:
Measurement of the foetal heart rate in childbirth is indicated:
Measurement of the foetal heart rate in childbirth is indicated:
1) On admission,
1) On admission,
1) On admission,
2) During the 1st stage of delivery:
2) During the 1st stage of delivery:
2) During the 1st stage of delivery:
Every 30 minutes among mothers and babies at low risk, and every 15 minutes if any risk is identified for the mother or foetus, and
Every 30 minutes among mothers and babies at low risk, and every 15 minutes if any risk is identified for the mother or foetus, and
Every 30 minutes among mothers and babies at low risk, and every 15 minutes if any risk is identified for the mother or foetus, and
3) Immediately after every contraction and at least every five minutes in the 2nd stage of delivery.
3) Immediately after every contraction and at least every five minutes in the 2nd stage of delivery.
3) Immediately after every contraction and at least every five minutes in the 2nd stage of delivery.
The lower limit for a normal foetal heart rate is defined as 110 beats per minute (bpm).
The lower limit for a normal foetal heart rate is defined as 110 beats per minute (bpm).
The lower limit for a normal foetal heart rate is defined as 110 beats per minute (bpm).
A heart rate below 100 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
A heart rate below 100 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
A heart rate below 100 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
The upper limit for a normal heart rate is 160 bpm.
The upper limit for a normal heart rate is 160 bpm.
The upper limit for a normal heart rate is 160 bpm.
A heart rate above 180 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
A heart rate above 180 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
A heart rate above 180 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is  necessary.
The foetal heart is best heard by placing the foetoscope over the back of the baby.
The foetal heart is best heard by placing the foetoscope over the back of the baby.
The foetal heart is best heard by placing the foetoscope over the back of the baby.
Always measure the foetal heart rate for one minute immediately after a contraction (you will need a watch).
Always measure the foetal heart rate for one minute immediately after a contraction (you will need a watch).
Always measure the foetal heart rate for one minute immediately after a contraction (you will need a watch).
Measuring the maternal pulse and the foetal heart rate simultaneously can help avoid a mix-up between the two.
Measuring the maternal pulse and the foetal heart rate simultaneously can exclude a mix-up between the two.
Measuring the maternal pulse and the foetal heart rate simultaneously can exclude a mix-up between the two.
Vacuum delivery is a “signal function” of basic emergency obstetric care, and so must be mastered by all skilled birth attendants.
Vacuum delivery is a “signal function” of basic emergency obstetric care, and so must be mastered by all skilled birth attendants.
Vacuum delivery is a “signal function” of basic emergency obstetric care, and so must be mastered by all skilled birth attendants.
When maternal efforts (pushing) fail or when there is a pathologic foetal heart rate in second stage of labour assisted vaginal delivery is indicated given the head is well engaged.

Prolonged second stage (over one hour of active pushing), maternal indications (maternal exhaustion), maternal medical illness (cardiac disease, hypertensive disorder) or non- reassuring foetal heart rate.

Prerequisites to instrument delivery are:
Prerequisites to instrument delivery are:
Prerequisites to instrument delivery are:

Vertex presentation, engagement in the pelvis (not more than 1/5 palpable above the pubic bone), complete dilatation of the cervix, rupture of membranes, empty bladder, no suspected true cephalopelvic disproportion, and willingness to stop the procedure if it does not go well.

Different types of vacuum extractors exist.
Different types of vacuum extractors exist.
Different types of vacuum extractors exist.
Most frequently used are the ones with metal or silicon cups and the hand-pump suction devices with a plastic cup.
Most frequently used are the ones with metal or silicon cups and the hand-pump suction devices with a plastic cup.
Most frequently used are the ones with metal or silicon cups and the hand-pump suction devices with a plastic cup.
Both can be used safely, the hand-pump devices have the benefit of the practitioner being in control for creating the vacuum, whilst with the other device an assistant is needed to operate the pump.

Both can be used safely, the hand-pump devices have the benefit of the practitioner being in control for creating the vacuum, whilst with the other device an assistant is needed to operate the pump.
Metal and plastic cups are less likely to “pop off” and therefore the risk of failure is only half compared to the soft silicon cups.
Metal and plastic cups are less likely to “pop off” and therefore the risk of failure is only half compared to the soft silicon cups.

Procedure
Procedure
With the suction off, the center of the cup should be applied 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel in the midline along the sagittal suture, the so-called the flexion point.
With the suction off, the center of the cup should be applied 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel in the midline along the sagittal suture, the so-called the Flexion point.
With the suction off, the center of the cup should be applied 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel in the midline along the sagittal suture, the so-called the Flexion point.
The flexion point is an important point in maximising traction and minimising detachment of the cup.
The flexion point is an important point in maximizing traction and minimizing detachment of the cup.
The flexion point is an important point in maximizing traction and minimizing detachment of the cup.
As most cups have a diameter of 5 to 7 cm the edge of the cup will be over the posterior fontanel.
As most cups have a diameter of 5 to 7 cm the edge of the cup will be over the posterior fontanel.

No maternal tissue, including the vagina, should be under the cup.

A finger is swept around the cup to make sure no maternal tissue is trapped beneath the cup.

Complications
Complications
A vacuum assisted delivery is not a procedure without any risks, and should therefore be used when indications and prerequisites exist.
A vacuum assisted delivery is not a procedure without any risks, and should therefore be used when indications and prerequisites exist.

Proper application of vacuum is essential.

Both mother and infant should be examined for birth trauma after its application.

Traction can speed up delivery in emergency situations only when there is cooperation from the patient with pushing.
Traction can speed up delivery in emergency situations only when there is cooperation from the patient with pushing.
Traction can speed up delivery in emergency situations only when there is cooperation from the patient with pushing.
Proper traction at right angles to the plane of the vacuum cup, and in the axis of traction, is necessary to avoid losing the vacuum.

Proper traction at right angles to the plane of the vacuum cup, and in the axis of traction, is necessary to avoid losing the vacuum.
One type of complication of vacuum delivery is subgaleal haematoma, on rare occasions it may be life threatening.
One type of complication of vacuum delivery is subgaleal hematoma, on rare occasions it may be life threatening.
One type of complication of vacuum delivery is subgaleal hematoma, on rare occasions it may be life threatening.
This occurs when emissary veins are damaged and blood accumulates in the potential space between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull.
This occurs when emissary veins are damaged and blood accumulates in the potential space between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull.
This occurs when emissary veins are damaged and blood accumulates in the potential space between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull.
Signs of subgaleal haematomas include diffuse swelling of the head that may shift dependently when the infant’s head is repositioned.
Signs of subgaleal hematomas include diffuse swelling of the head that may shift dependently when the infant’s head is repositioned.
Signs of subgaleal hematomas include diffuse swelling of the head that may shift dependently when the infant’s head is repositioned.
This swelling indents easily on palpation and may be significant enough to result in hypovolemic shock.
This swelling indents easily on palpation and may be significant enough to result in hypovolemic shock.
This swelling indents easily on palpation and may be significant enough to result in hypovolemic shock.
It is treated with a pressure bandage and replacement of volume if needed.
It is treated with a pressure bandage and replacement of volume if needed.
It is treated with a pressure bandage and replacement of volume if needed.

Subgaleal haematoma is quite different than a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood that accumulates under the periosteum of a skull bone (usually the parietal) and is characteristically limited to the confines of the cranial bone and therefore the amount of bleeding will not become dangerous.

Subgaleal hematoma is quite different than a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood that accumulates under the periosteum of a skull bone (usually the parietal) and is characteristically limited to the confines of the cranial bone and therefore the amount of bleeding will not become dangerous.

Intracranial haemorrhage is a rare complication that may be life threatening, the risk is higher in the severely premature baby, therefore vacuum extraction should ideally not be applied before 36 weeks of gestation.

Intracranial haemorrhage is a rare complication that may be life threatening, the risk is higher in the severe premature baby, therefore vacuum extraction should ideally not be applied before 36 weeks of gestation.

Vacuum delivery also increases the risk of maternal trauma, so the procedure should be performed only on a well established indication and assess carefully any trauma to the birth canal especially the anal sphincter by performing a rectal digital exploration.

Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.

Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

NG tubes can also be used for enteral feeding of infants.

Insertion of a nasogastric tube:
Insertion of a nasogastric tube:
Insertion of a nasogastric tube:
Holding the tip of the tube against the child’s nose, measure the distance from the nose to the ear lobe, then to the xiphisternum (epigastrium). Mark the tube at this point.
Holding the tip of the tube against the child’s nose, measure the distance from the nose to the ear lobe, then to the xiphisternum (epigastrium). Mark the tube at this point.
Holding the tip of the tube against the child’s nose, measure the distance from the nose to the ear lobe, then to the xiphisternum (epigastrium). Mark the tube at this point.

Hold the child firmly. Lubricate the tip of the catheter with water, and pass it directly into one nostril, pushing it slowly in. It should pass easily down into the stomach without resistance. When the measured distance is reached, fix the tube with tape at the nose.

Hold the child firmly. Lubricate the tip of the catheter with water, and pass it directly into one nostril, pushing it slowly in. It should pass easily down into the stomach without resistance. When the measured distance is reached, fix the tube with tape at the nose.

Hold the child firmly. Lubricate the tip of the catheter with water, and pass it directly into one nostril, pushing it slowly in. It should pass easily down into the stomach without resistance. When the measured distance is reached, fix the tube with tape at the nose.

Aspirate a small amount of stomach contents with a syringe to confirm that the tube is in place (if available check that it turns blue lithmus paper pink). If no aspirate is obtained, inject air down the tube and listen over the abdomen with a stethoscope.

Aspirate a small amount of stomach contents with a syringe to confirm that the tube is in place (if available check that it turns blue lithmus paper pink). If no aspirate is obtained, inject air down the tube and listen over the abdomen with a stethoscope.

If there is any doubt about the location of the tube, withdraw it and start again.
If there is any doubt about the location of the tube, withdraw it and start again.
If there is any doubt about the location of the tube, withdraw it and start again.
When the tube is in place, fix a 20 ml syringe (without the plunger) to the end of the tube, and pour food or fluid into the syringe, allowing it to flow by gravity.
